sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_1:
Find the determinant of the matrix:
$$
\begin{bmatrix}
3 & 1 & 2\\
0 & -2 & 1\\
-2 & 0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}
$$
message_2:
To find the determinant of the given 3x3 matrix, we can use the following formula:

$$
\det(A) = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)
$$

where a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, and i are the elements of the matrix:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
a & b & c\\
d & e & f\\
g & h & i
\end{bmatrix}
$$

In our case, the matrix is:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
3 & 1 & 2\\
0 & -2 & 1\\
-2 & 0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}
$$

So, a = 3, b = 1, c = 2, d = 0, e = -2, f = 1, g = -2, h = 0, and i = 1.

Now, we can plug these values into the determinant formula:

$$
\det(A) = 3((-2)(1) - (1)(0)) - 1((0)(1) - (1)(-2)(1)) + 2((0)(0) - (-2)(-2))
$$

$$
\det(A) = 3(-2) - 1(0 - 2) + 2(0 - 4)
$$

$$
\det(A) = -6 + 2 - 8
$$

$$
\det(A) = -12
$$

So, the determinant of the given matrix is -12.
